bibl.note: The following document is a letter written by John Hunt in New Tazewell to his brother David in Franklin County and dated June 19, 1835. In the letter, John explains that he plans to retire from his 18 years as sheriff and move to the rich lands of the Missouri River.

div1.p: having an opertunity at this time to drop you a line by Mr Martin I can inform you that the family are all well at presant only Rhody the pain in hir breast gets wors constantly I am looking constantly for hir to take hir bead She Still keeps a bout the greater part of hir time I am Very much trobeled with pains in my Joints I have no means thats is worth communicating to you, I have had 2 letters from my children that has gon to the mosoriee the rite the have got in a contry of Rich land and is very productive fine range gain in great quality Honey plenty I intend going out there in April next to See the contry I cannot go any Sooner on the account of my business as Shff I will try to wind up this fall and winter I have served as Sheriff 18 years come march next and I think it is time for me to quit as I am geting old and tired of the business F.S. Hunt is Running for the legislator and will be Elected very Easy James Overton is his a ponant who you know has no tallents for nothing in the world he tells the people he is a farmer and he goes for the farmers intrusts, ourt crops of small grain is very much infered by the wet it has rained in this county Every day for 3 or 4 weeks more or less I believe Fidilo was at taledego a fiew days Since at his unkle georges the was all well he likes that contry very well please rite to me as I would be glad to hear from you give my Respects to John & Henry Lurkins all the friends it is likely I will pass throug your contry one time mor if I Ever Should get any thing of Mayfield and if not I do not Expect Ever to See you again So I am most respectfully your brother till death
